p:
The simplified model in Equation 8, along with the model developed by Rouzine and Rozhnova (2018), is analogous to the traveling wave (TW) models of rapidly adapting asexual populations that have been studied extensively over the past two decades ( Tsimring et al., 1996; Desai and Fisher, 2007; Rouzine et al., 2003; Hallatschek, 2011), see Neher (2013a) for a review. These models describe large populations that generate beneficial mutations rapidly enough that many strains co-circulate and compete against each other. The fittest (most antigenically advanced) strains are often multiple mutational steps,
q
, ahead of the most common strains, see Figure 3D. This ‘nose’ of the fitness distributions contains the strains that dominate in the future and the only adaptive mutations that fixate in the population arise in pioneer strains in the nose. Consequently, the rate with which antigenic mutations establish in the population is controlled by the rate at which they arise in the nose ( Desai and Fisher, 2007). If the growth rate at the nose of the distribution,
x n
, is much higher than antigenic mutation rate,
x n
≫ m
, it takes typically
(10)
τ a
=
log ⁡
(
x n
/ m
)
x n
generations before a novel antigenic mutation arises in a newly arisen pioneer strain that grows exponentially with rate
x n
. The advancement of the nose is balanced rapidly by the increasing population mean fitness.
